summary: This is an emergency motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, seeking a stay to prevent the unsealing of her deposition transcripts from a prior civil defamation case. The motion argues unsealing would violate her Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights, moot her appeal, and sanction an alleged government violation of a protective order.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The movant seeking to stay the unsealing of her deposition transcripts. She is under indictment, accused of perjury and facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's abuse.

persons.name: Adam Mueller
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who signed and filed this emergency motion.

persons.name: Ty Gee
persons.context: Listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell on the motion.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell on the motion; her declaration was filed in support of an objection.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The district judge who issued the order to unseal the deposition material, which is being appealed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Held a press conference after Maxwell's arrest, commenting on her alleged guilt and credibility.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Attorney for the plaintiff (Virginia Giuffre) who made public comments opining that Maxwell was a 'main facilitator' of Epstein's crimes.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Attorney for the plaintiff (Virginia Giuffre) listed as opposing counsel; made public comments praising prosecutors and calling Maxwell the 'central figure'.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding over Maxwell's criminal case; admonished counsel about extrajudicial comments to protect Maxwell's right to a fair trial.

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: Previously presided in the civil case, denying Maxwell's motion to stay her deposition pending investigation disclosure.

persons.name: Judge Pooler
persons.context: Dissented in part in the prior appellate decision (Brown v. Maxwell), advocating for a more limited unsealing.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier; the motion states the defamation claim centered on allegations Maxwell participated in his scheme to sexually abuse and traffic minors.

persons.name: Doe 1
persons.context: A third party whose deposition was also taken under the protective order and is subject to the unsealing order. Relied on confidentiality.

persons.name: Stephanie Poole
persons.context: Person who certified service of the motion.

connections.description: The motion references allegations that Maxwell participated in Epstein's scheme to sexually abuse and traffic minors.
Mueller is filing this emergency motion as an attorney representing Maxwell.
McCawley is opposing counsel in the underlying civil case and made public statements against Maxwell.
Edwards is counsel for the plaintiff and made public statements accusing Maxwell of facilitating crimes.
Both gave depositions under the same protective order in the civil case, relying on its confidentiality.
Both are listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell on this motion.
Both are listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell on this motion.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave deposition testimony in the civil defamation case, which was designated confidential under a protective order.

events.title: Maxwell's Arrest
events.description: The government staged a forced entry at dawn into Ghislaine Maxwell's home and arrested her.

events.title: Superseding Indictment Filed
events.description: The government filed a superseding indictment alleging Maxwell facilitated Epstein's abuse and committed perjury in her 2016 deposition.

events.title: Unsealing Order
events.description: Judge Loretta Preska ordered the unsealing of Maxwell's and Doe 1's deposition transcripts and related materials.

events.title: Motion to Reconsider Denied
events.description: Judge Preska denied Maxwell's motion to reconsider the unsealing order but granted a two-business-day stay until August 3.

events.title: Notice of Appeal Filed
events.description: Maxwell filed a notice of appeal from the district court's unsealing order.

events.title: Brown v. Maxwell Appeal
events.description: The Second Circuit reversed a district court decision and ordered unsealing of summary judgment materials, remanding for review of other records.

locations: Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The government possesses Ghislaine Maxwell's sealed deposition transcripts and quotes them in her indictment, allegedly in violation of a protective order that contained no law enforcement exception.

Maxwell's attorneys argue the unsealing would violate her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and Sixth Amendment right to a fair trial by exposing potential jurors to prejudicial information.
The motion claims the plaintiff's counsel and the government set a 'perjury trap' by taking Maxwell's deposition under a promise of confidentiality and then using it for criminal charges.
The district court ordered the deposition material unsealed on August 3, 2020, prompting this emergency motion for a stay to prevent the appeal from becoming moot.
The motion references a prior violation of the protective order by the plaintiff's successor counsel, Cooper & Kirk, who were ordered to destroy materials received.
